questions.question: According to the 2-minute rule, what should you do with tasks that take less than 2 minutes?
options: Add them to your to-do list for later
Do them immediately
Delegate them to someone else
Schedule them for tomorrow
questions.explanation: The 2-minute rule states that if a task takes less than 2 minutes, you should do it immediately instead of adding it to your to-do list.

questions.title: Morning Email Scenario
questions.context: You've just arrived at work and opened your email inbox. You have 47 unread emails and a team meeting in 30 minutes.
questions.scenario: Among your emails, you notice: a quick reply needed for a colleague's question (2 minutes), a complex project proposal that requires analysis (45 minutes), and a simple expense report approval (90 seconds).
questions.question: Following the 2-minute rule, what should you do first?
options: Start with the complex project proposal since it's most important
Handle the quick reply and expense approval immediately, then prepare for the meeting
Save all emails for after the meeting to give them proper attention
Delegate the expense approval and focus on the project proposal
questions.explanation: The 2-minute rule suggests handling quick tasks immediately. Both the reply (2 min) and approval (90 sec) should be done right away, leaving you organized for the meeting while the complex proposal can be scheduled for later.

questions.question: What is the main benefit of following the 2-minute rule?
options: It helps you work faster
It reduces mental clutter from small tasks
It makes you more organized
It saves money
questions.explanation: The main benefit is reducing mental clutter by preventing small tasks from accumulating on your to-do list.

questions.question: What is time blocking?
options: Avoiding distractions during work
Scheduling specific time slots for different activities
Working in short bursts with breaks
Blocking out interruptions
questions.explanation: Time blocking is the practice of scheduling specific time slots for different types of work or activities on your calendar.

questions.title: Weekly Planning Challenge
questions.context: You're planning your work week and have identified your peak energy hours are 9-11 AM. You have several tasks to schedule.
questions.scenario: Your tasks include: writing a strategic report (requires deep focus, 3 hours), attending routine team meetings (low energy required), responding to emails (moderate focus), and creative brainstorming for a new project (high energy needed).
questions.question: How should you structure your 9-11 AM time blocks this week?
options: Schedule routine meetings since they're easier to handle when you're fresh
Block this time for strategic report writing and creative brainstorming
Use this time for email responses to clear your inbox
Keep this time flexible for whatever seems urgent each day
questions.explanation: Peak energy hours should be reserved for your most demanding tasks that require deep focus and creativity. Strategic work and brainstorming are perfect for when your mental energy is highest.

questions.question: Why should you include buffer time between time blocks?
options: To have time for social media
To account for tasks running over or transitions
To take longer breaks
To avoid working too hard
questions.explanation: Buffer time helps account for tasks that might run over their scheduled time and provides transition time between different activities.

questions.question: What is the most important aspect of active listening?
options: Thinking about your response while they talk
Giving your full attention to the speaker
Taking detailed notes
Nodding frequently
questions.explanation: Active listening requires giving your full attention to the speaker and truly focusing on understanding their message.

questions.title: Difficult Conversation at Work
questions.context: Your teammate Sarah approaches you looking frustrated. She says: 'I feel like my ideas are never heard in our team meetings. Every time I suggest something, it gets overlooked or someone else gets credit for a similar idea later.'
questions.scenario: Sarah is clearly upset and needs to feel heard. You want to practice active listening to understand her perspective and help her feel supported.
questions.question: What's the best active listening response?
options: That's terrible! You should definitely talk to our manager about this right away.
I hear that you're feeling frustrated because your contributions aren't being recognized in meetings. Can you tell me more about what that experience is like for you?
Oh, I'm sure people do hear your ideas. Maybe you just need to speak up more confidently.
Have you tried writing your ideas down before meetings? That might help you present them better.
questions.explanation: This response demonstrates active listening by paraphrasing what Sarah shared, acknowledging her emotions, and asking an open-ended question to encourage her to share more. It shows you're fully engaged and focused on understanding her experience.

questions.question: What should you do with distractions during a conversation?
options: Check them quickly without the speaker noticing
Put them away completely
Multitask efficiently
Address them immediately
questions.explanation: To practice active listening, you should put away all distractions and give the speaker your undivided attention.

questions.question: How much time can meal prep typically save per week?
options: 30 minutes
1 hour
2-3 hours
5-6 hours
questions.explanation: Meal prep can typically save 2-3 hours per week that would otherwise be spent on daily cooking and meal decisions.

questions.title: Sunday Meal Prep Dilemma
questions.context: It's Sunday afternoon and you want to start meal prepping, but you're feeling overwhelmed. You work long hours during the week and often end up ordering takeout because you're too tired to cook.
questions.scenario: You have 3 hours available today. You're considering: prepping all breakfast, lunch, and dinner for the entire week; preparing just lunches for 5 days; or cooking a big batch of one versatile ingredient you can use in different ways.
questions.question: What's the best approach for a meal prep beginner?
options: Prep all meals for the week to maximize your Sunday effort
Focus on preparing just lunches for the work week
Cook one big batch meal like chili that you can eat all week
Prep ingredients but not complete meals to maintain flexibility
questions.explanation: For beginners, focusing on one meal type (like lunches) is more manageable and sustainable. It provides immediate weekday relief without the overwhelm of prepping everything, helping you build the habit successfully.

questions.question: What's a key benefit of preparing components rather than complete meals?
options: It takes less time
It's more nutritious
It provides variety and flexibility
It costs less money
questions.explanation: Preparing components (grains, proteins, vegetables) separately allows you to mix and match throughout the week, providing variety and preventing meal fatigue.

questions.question: What makes compound interest so powerful?
options: You earn interest on your initial investment only
You earn interest on both your investment and previous interest
It guarantees high returns
It's risk-free
questions.explanation: Compound interest is powerful because you earn returns not just on your original investment, but also on all the interest/returns you've previously earned.

questions.title: Investment Decision at 30
questions.context: Alex is 30 years old and just got a promotion with a $200/month salary increase. They're debt-free and have a 6-month emergency fund saved up.
questions.scenario: Alex is considering three options: investing the extra $200/month in a retirement account, saving it in a high-yield savings account for a house down payment in 5 years, or using it to increase their lifestyle (dining out, entertainment, etc.).
questions.question: From a compound interest perspective, what would be the most financially beneficial long-term choice?
options: Save in high-yield savings for the house down payment
Invest in retirement account to maximize compound growth over 35+ years
Use it for lifestyle improvements to enjoy life now
Split it equally between savings and lifestyle improvements
questions.explanation: With 35+ years until retirement, investing in a retirement account gives compound interest the maximum time to work. Even small amounts invested consistently over decades can grow to substantial sums due to compounding returns.

questions.question: What is the most important factor in maximizing compound interest?
options: Investing large amounts
Choosing the highest risk investments
Starting early and giving time for growth
Checking your investments daily
questions.explanation: Time is the most crucial factor in compound interest - starting early allows more time for your money to grow exponentially.
